title: How often are you asked if you've written someone into your book? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s probably the most common question I get. There seems to be some illicit thrill to the idea that a writer might write real-life people into a work of fiction, as if it were somehow illegal or immoral; as if we writers are secretly eavesdropping and recording everyday life in order to best represent our experience of the human condition. Sorry to disappoint: I make no secret about it. Eavesdropping shamelessly is my job. If you don’t want to be in a book, stay in your house with the shades drawn.

All… The… Time… It’s completely my own fault though - A lot of the characters in my novels are ‘loosely’ based on real people. Friends mostly, whose foibles I know and can write into the story - It gives me a ‘leg up’ on deciding what characters will do under certain circumstances. It also means that I can just wheel out a short story with ‘their’ character as the star, instead of buying them a costly Birthday present. However, certain people have started to expect this, and it can become a bit of a bind. I guess it’s the price I pay for lazy characterisation…
